repository.corpname: Kheel Center for Labor-Management Documentation & Archives

did.abstract: Photocopy of first contract between the New York Joint Board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America and the New York Clothing Manufacturers' Exchange, signed in 1924, as well as a letter of transmittal from Sidney Orenstein to Jack Sheinkman from 1994.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of a photocopy of first contract between the New York Joint Board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America and the New York Clothing Manufacturers' Exchange, signed in 1924, and a letter of transmittal from Sidney Orenstein to Jack Sheinkman from 1994.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to the collections in the Kheel Center is restricted. Please contact a reference archivist for access to these materials.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This collection must be used in keeping with the Kheel Center Information Sheet and Procedures for Document Use.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: ACWA Collective Bargaining Agreement #5973m. Kheel Center for Labor-Management Documentation and Archives, Cornell University Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America (ACWA) was a United States labor union known for its support for "social unionism" and progressive political causes. Led by Sidney Hillman for its first thirty years, it helped found the Congress of Industrial Organizations. It merged with the Textile Workers Union of America (TWUA) in 1976 to form the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union (ACTWU), which merged with the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union in 1995 to create the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees (UNITE). UNITE merged in 2004 with the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union (HERE) in 2004 to create a new union known as UNITE HERE. After a bitter internal dispute in 2009, the majority of the UNITE side of the union, along with some of the disgruntled HERE locals left UNITE HERE, and formed a new union named Workers United, led by former UNITE president Bruce Raynor.
